title: 106_s1468
content: The Act may be cited as the "United States Capitol Visitor Center Commemorative Coin Act of 1999". Congress acknowledges the historical significance of the Capitol building, its importance as a symbol of democracy, the need for improved visitor facilities, the security provided by the Capitol Police, and the funding allocated for the construction of the Capitol Visitor Center. Congress has allocated $100,000,000, along with private funds, to build a Capitol Visitor Center for security and visitor education. They encourage voluntary fundraising for the project and authorize coins to support the construction, maintenance, and preservation of the center. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue bimetallic $10 coins, $1 silver coins, and half dollar clad coins with specific weights, diameters, and compositions. The Secretary of the Treasury may mint and issue bimetallic $10 coins, $1 silver coins, and half dollar clad coins with specific weights, diameters, and compositions. Additionally, if bimetallic coins are not feasible, $5 gold coins may be minted instead. The mintage levels specified in the subsection may be waived as per the relevant section of the United States Code. The $5 coins minted under this Act shall weigh 8.359 grams, have a diameter of 0.850 inches, and contain 90% gold and 10% alloy. Mintage levels specified in subsection (a) may be waived. The coins shall be legal tender. The Secretary will obtain platinum and gold for minting coins from available sources, and may obtain silver from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design of the coins will be determined under this Act. Design requirements for the coins minted under this Act include being emblematic of the first meeting of the United States Congress in the Capitol Building. Each coin must have a value designation, the year "2000" inscribed, and include words like "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the United States Capitol Preservation Commission and the Commission of Fine Arts. The design for the coins minted under this Act will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the United States Capitol Preservation Commission, the Commission of Fine Arts, and the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 6. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities, with only one facility of the United States Mint allowed to strike each combination of denomination and quality. These coins will be the first commemorative coins of the United States to bear the year "2000" inscription. The Secretary will consult with the Commission to establish a role for promoting, advertising, and marketing the coins, and may enter into a contract with the Commission or a designated entity for this purpose. The Secretary may enter into a contract with the Commission or a designated entity for promoting and marketing the coins minted under this Act. SEC. 7. SALE OF COINS. The coins minted under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value of the coins, a surcharge, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount on sale prices. All sales will include a surcharge. The Secretary will accept prepaid orders for coins minted under this Act before issuance, with sale prices at a reasonable discount. Sales will include a surcharge established by the Secretary, varying by coin denomination. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. Surcharges from coin sales will go to the Capitol Preservation Fund for the Capitol Visitor Center.
